name: Adaptive Cognitive Gaming Support
description: ALFRED provides personalized cognitive games tailored to the diverse preferences, privacy concerns, and motivation levels of older adults like Olivia and Elena, enabling effective engagement and stimulation while allowing caregivers like Mike and Sarah to monitor progress respectfully and unobtrusively.
scenario:
Olivia, feeling wary as always about technology, reluctantly agreed to try the cognitive games ALFRED suggested, but only after explicitly instructing the system to keep notifications to a bare minimum and to never share her data with anyone—not even her caregivers or family. She used the push-to-talk feature cautiously, avoiding spontaneous voice commands because she found the idea of ALFRED activating on its own intrusive and unsettling. When ALFRED suggested a memory game that involved some light physical movement, Olivia dismissed it immediately, unwilling to engage with anything remotely challenging or that felt like a simulation. She preferred simple, predictable interactions and grew frustrated when the assistant occasionally tried to encourage her toward more stimulating exercises.

Meanwhile, Elena embraced ALFRED’s offerings with enthusiasm. She welcomed the detailed explanations the system provided about how each game worked and was eager to try the more demanding cognitive and physical challenges. Elena didn’t mind the frequent notifications and often found herself motivated by ALFRED’s encouragements and progress tracking. She even used the option to chat spontaneously with other users during game sessions to stave off loneliness, something Olivia would never tolerate. Elena’s openness to sharing her health data and participation in video check-ins made her feel more connected to her caregivers and motivated to improve.

Mike, the registered nurse, found himself frustrated by Olivia’s stringent privacy settings and reluctance to share data. He struggled to monitor her progress effectively, often relying on infrequent offline check-ins instead of the preferred video calls. He wished Olivia would agree to more open data sharing to better tailor care plans but respected her wishes, focusing instead on Elena, whose data was more accessible and who actively welcomed his involvement. Mike’s clinical mindset made him dismiss the social and emotional benefits Elena sought from gaming, yet he acknowledged that her engagement seemed to support her overall wellbeing.

Sarah, the informal caregiver, juggled both Olivia’s and Elena’s differing preferences with patience and pragmatism. She appreciated ALFRED’s flexibility but found managing the conflicting demands exhausting. For Olivia, she disabled most game-related notifications and avoided pushing for participation, instead focusing on discreet monitoring. With Elena, Sarah encouraged more frequent game sessions, occasionally joining in to foster bonding and emotional support. Sarah valued the system’s ability to respect each older adult’s autonomy while providing her the tools to tailor care, even though it meant constantly switching between very different approaches. The tension between Olivia’s guarded, formal interaction style and Elena’s open, tech-curious attitude created a daily challenge, but ALFRED’s adaptive cognitive gaming support allowed both women to engage on their own terms, however different those terms were.
